com.oceanoptics.omnidriver.features.networkconfigure

Interface NetworkConfigure


  • public interface NetworkConfigure
    This interface encapsulates functions in devices that have network capability. Networks on a spectrometer may have more than one interface.

    • Method Summary

    • Method Detail

      • isDHCPEnabled

        boolean isDHCPEnabled(int iface)
        Query whether the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) has been enabled for the indicated interface. DHCP allows a device that has been connected to a network to request an Internet Protocol (IP) address. Using DHCP is usually an alternative to manually setting a fixed IP address.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        Returns:
        true if DHCP is enabled, false otherwise.

      • setDHCPEnable

        void setDHCPEnable(int iface,
                   boolean enable)
        Change whether the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is enabled for the indicated interface. DHCP allows a device that has been connected to a network to request an Internet Protocol (IP) address. Using DHCP is usually an alternative to manually setting a fixed IP address.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        enable - true to enable DHCP, false otherwise. If DHCP is not enabled, it may be necessary to specify a fixed address for the device to use or it may stop communicating.

      • getIPv4Address

        IPv4SubnetAddress getIPv4Address(int iface,
                                 int addrIndex)
        Get an Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) address that have been assigned to the indicated interface. An interface usually has just one IP address, but it is possible for it to have several.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        addrIndex - address slot location
        Returns:
        An IPv4 address.

      • addIPv4Address

        void addIPv4Address(int iface,
                    IPv4SubnetAddress address)
        Add an IPv4 address to the indicated interface.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        address - The Internet Protocol address to add to the interface.

      • removeIPv4Address

        void removeIPv4Address(int iface,
                       int addrIndex)
        Remove an IPv4 address from the indicated interface.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        addrIndex - The index of the address to remove

      • getIPv4Gateway

        IPv4Address getIPv4Gateway(int iface)
        Get the IPv4 address for the local gateway. The gateway is the address that packets intended for a recipient outside of the local subnet should be sent to. The machine at the gateway address is responsible for forwarding these onto one of its other interfaces to get the packet closer to its final destination.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        Returns:
        Returns the address of the local network gateway.

      • setIPv4Gateway

        void setIPv4Gateway(int iface,
                    IPv4Address address)
        Set the IPv4 address for the local gateway. The gateway is the address that packets intended for a recipient outside of the local subnet should be sent to. The machine at the gateway address is responsible for forwarding these onto one of its other interfaces to get the packet closer to its final destination.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        address - The address of the network gateway

      • supportsMulticast

        boolean supportsMulticast()
        Query whether the network layer supports multicast transmissions.
        Returns:
        true if multicast is supported, false otherwise.

      • writeMACAddress

        void writeMACAddress(int iface,
                     java.lang.String address)
              throws java.io.IOException
        Write the MAC address to a specific network interface.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        address - string ex. 00:19:ad:1d:15:21
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • readMACAddress

        java.lang.String readMACAddress(int iface)
                         throws java.io.IOException
        Read the MAC address from a specific network interface.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        Returns:
        string in form 00:19:ad:1d:15:21
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • runSelfTest

        boolean runSelfTest(int iface)
             throws java.io.IOException
        Run network interface test. If unit is connected Ethernet: Attempts to acquire an address via DHCP. This can take up to 120 seconds if not found. After the test the device loads normal settings from non-volatile storage. If unit is connected Wireless: The SSID is temporarily set to OOI and security set to open. Performs steps as if connected via Ethernet.
        Parameters:
        iface -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • getNumberOfInterfaces

        int getNumberOfInterfaces()
        Get the number of network interfaces available through this Feature.
        Returns:
        The number of network interfaces that can be accessed

      • isInterfaceEnabled

        boolean isInterfaceEnabled(int iface)
        Query whether a given network interface is enabled. Note that even if an interface is enabled, it may not be able to communicate unless other communication options (such as a network address) are properly configured.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        Returns:
        true if the network interface is enabled, false otherwise.

      • setInterfaceEnable

        void setInterfaceEnable(int iface,
                        boolean enable)
        Change the enable status of a given network interface. Note that even if an interface is enabled, it may not be able to communicate unless other communication options (such as a network address) are properly configured.
        Parameters:
        iface - network interface (0 - wired; 1 - WiFi)
        enable - true to enable the interface, false to disable it.

      • saveSettings

        void saveSettings()
        Save the current settings for the network interface. Note that some devices may save the settings as soon as they are changed, so this may not always have any real effect.

      • hasGigabitEnable

        boolean hasGigabitEnable()
        Queries whether the device supports enabling or disabling gigabit Ethernet. It is assumed that if gigabit is disabled that the device will negotiate at slower speeds such as 10/100.
        Returns:
        true if it is possible to set the gigabit Ethernet enable status, false otherwise.

      • isGigabitEnabled

        boolean isGigabitEnabled()
        Query whether the indicated interface is configured for Gigabit Ethernet
        Returns:
        true if the interface can negotiate gigabit speeds, false otherwise.

      • setGigabitEnable

        void setGigabitEnable(boolean enable)
        Set whether the indicated interface should allow Gigabit Ethernet. Note that enabling gigabit speeds increases the power consumption of the device, with a corresponding increase in generated heat. This should not be turned on unless the application requires greater than 100Mbit/s, and/or if there is a concern that a slower device on the bus may saturate the available bus time over a critical shared link. Not all devices will support this command, so call hasGigabitEnable() to determine if this is allowed.
        Parameters:
        enable - true to allow the device to negotiate up to gigabit speeds, false to limit it to lower (10/100) rates.

      • getSSID

        WiFiSSID getSSID()
        Get the identifier of the network that the device will connect to. The Service Set Identifier (SSID) effectively names the wireless network to allow hosts to find the correct one when multiple networks may overlap within a particular physical space.
        Returns:
        The SSID that has been configured for this interface

      • setSSID

        void setSSID(WiFiSSID id)
        Set the identifier for the network that the device should connect to. The Service Set Identifier (SSID) effectively names the wireless network to allow hosts to find the correct one when multiple networks may overlap within a particular physical space.
        Parameters:
        id - An object describing the SSID for this interface

      • getWiFiMode

        java.lang.String getWiFiMode()
        Retrieve the role of the device within the wireless network. For example, WiFi adapters may be configured as clients of an existing wireless network, or as access points at the center of their own network.
        Returns:
        A descriptor for the wireless mode configuration in the device

      • setWiFiMode

        void setWiFiMode(java.lang.String mode)
        Set the role of the device within the wireless network. For example, WiFi adapters may be configured as clients of an existing wireless network, or as access points at the center of their own network. Note that the modes accepted by the WiFi adapter may vary from one device to the next.
        Parameters:
        mode - The mode in which the device should operate

      • getWiFiSecurity

        java.lang.String getWiFiSecurity()
        Get the wireless security protocol used to connect to the network. Unless other measures are taken, wireless network packets are broadcast "in the clear" such that any other device could silently capture and interpret them. Various approaches exist for preventing wireless network traffic from being decoded by devices that are not properly authenticated. This method retrieves the current setting for whether and how wireless transmissions are secured.
        Returns:
        A descriptor for the wireless security strategy being used

      • setWiFiSecurity

        void setWiFiSecurity(java.lang.String mode)
        Set the wireless security protocol used to connect to the network. Unless other measures are taken, wireless network packets are broadcast "in the clear" such that any other device could silently capture and interpret them. Various approaches exist for preventing wireless network traffic from being decoded by devices that are not properly authenticated. This method retrieves the current setting for whether and how wireless transmissions are secured.
        Parameters:
        mode - New security mode to use

      • setWiFiPassphrase

        void setWiFiPassphrase(WiFiPassphrase passPhrase)
        Set the security code necessary to connect to the network. When network traffic is encrypted, some sort of key is required for the devices within the network is required to properly encode and decode packets. This method allows the wireless network key to be set.
        Parameters:
        passPhrase - An object describing the passphrase or encryption key required to communicate on the indicated wireless network

      • isDhcpServer

        boolean isDhcpServer()
        Query whether the indicated interface is configured for DHCP server
        Returns:
        true if the interface uses DHCP server, false otherwise.

      • setDhcpServer

        void setDhcpServer(boolean enable)
        Toggle whether the indicated interface should allow configuration of a DHCP service.
        Parameters:
        enable - true to allow the device configure a DHCP server.

      • getDhcpBaseAddress

        IPv4SubnetAddress getDhcpBaseAddress()
        Get a Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) address range for a DHCP server that has been assigned to the indicated interface.
        Returns:
        An IPv4 base address and associated subnet

      • setDhcpBaseAddress

        void setDhcpBaseAddress(IPv4SubnetAddress address)
        Set an IPv4 DHCP base address to the indicated interface.
        Parameters:
        address - The Internet Protocol base address to add to the interface.
